    Specifying Copula Models through Correlation

    Chase Mathis

    2025-08-27

    Simple-Copula-Parametrization.Rmd
    library(causl)
    ## Loading required package: rje
    ## Loading required package: VineCopula

    The standard way we choose to parametrize copula dependence structure is similar to the way we parametrize the other causal structures. We specify a variable is a link function of a linear combination of other variables.

    For instance, we return to the following example: Z∼N(0,1)X∣Z=z∼N(0.5×z,1)Y∣do(X=x)∼N(0.3×x,1)\begin{align*} Z &\sim N(0, \; 1)\\ X \mid Z=z &\sim N(0.5\times z, \; 1)\\ Y \mid \operatorname{do}(X=x) &\sim N(0.3\times x, \; 1) \end{align*}

    The formulas and family variables are familiar.

    formulas=list(z~1, x~z, y~x, ~1)
family=rep(1,4)

    When defining the pars variable we replace the familiar beta in the cop entry to a tau. If the user specifies a τ\tau, the program will convert the specified Kendall’s τ\tau to the correct parameter so that the copula between the outcome and confounder has a Kendall correlation of τ\tau. This is a simpler way to encode the dependence information as τ∈[−1,1]\tau \in [-1,1] and easier to interpret. The code looks like.

    pars <- list(z = list(beta = 0, phi=1),
             x = list(beta = c(0,0.5), phi=1),
             y = list(beta = c(0,0.3), phi=1),
             cop = list(y= list(z = list(tau = 0.25)))) # NOTE tau argument

    We note that we define the dependence between y and z to be uncoditional on the treatment x. This assumption is necessary for specifying Kendall’s τ\tau. (Is it?)

    cm <- causl_model(formulas = formulas, family = family, pars = pars)
dat <- rfrugal(n = 10000, causl_model = cm)
    ## Inversion method selected: using pair-copula parameterization

    Developed by Robin Evans, Xi Lin.
